Author: 24 March 2020
Review: A film about age that aged well, about the history of cinema made by professionals who have been important in that history, and about bad scripts with an excellent one
Review_Url: Great film! Amazing direction, script, cinematography, acting. Interesting drama and quasi-thriller, as the ageing issue is there, but also a noir-type situation in which the leading role character gets increasingly trapped. Gloria Swanson is perfect for her role. The manor is beautiful and kind of creepy at once. It is a film about age that aged very well, a motion picture about the history of cinema made by professionals who have been important in that history, and a movie about bad scripts with an excellent one. Just one final commnent: I could not help but, throughout the movie, I saw Tom Hanks's face in many of William Holden's facial expressions!

Author: 3 March 2000
Review_Url: This movie is true genius.  The fantastic and intriguing opening scene, the deep story line, and even the similarities between the characters and the real life people who play them make for one of the greatest movies of all time.

Author: 2 May 2016
Review: A Hollywood Classic about the fleeting nature of fame
Review_Url: This film was a great commentary on the superficial and fleeting nature of fame. Joe Gillis, a down on his luck screenwriter, happens upon the one-time Hollywood Gem Norma Desmond who sees Gillis as a way to relaunch her flagging film-career. Hollywood Boulevard brilliantly portrays the harsh and brutal nature of Hollywood. It is pathetic seeing Norma Desmond, sitting in the dark watching her old films, but it is also poignant and sad too. She was once a massive Hollywood star, but now everybody has even forgotten that she existed. To be launched into fame and then to have this fame taken away from you would be difficult to deal with for anyone let alone a has-been actress like Norma Desmond.

Author: 17 May 2019
Review_Url: When much too wordy for a dead guy narrator William Holden tells us about the dark ominous mansion he's happened upon, the direction and atmosphere doesn't match up. He could be walking up to a drugstore in the middle of a busy intersection and it'd be equally as suspenseful.

Author: 8 February 2015
Review_Url: In my opinion Sunset Boulevard was a bland film that left me completely indifferent. The thing I disliked the most about this film was the character development. Joe along with the rest of the characters were two dimensional and flat. The acting by Gloria Swanson was distasteful and overdone which made the film more of a soup opera with an uninteresting story line. I had high expectations after watching Wilder's some like it hot but after watching Sunset Boulevard I was not impressed. Author: 22 August 2013
Review: Undoubtedly one of the greatest American films of all time
Review_Url: Sunset Blvd. is an absolute masterpiece. From the first word spoken to the last you can see and hear how well written the script was.

Author: 13 August 2014
Review: Sunset Boulevard, twisting boulevard, every turn a little scary....
Review_Url: So sings the Joe Gillis character in the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical version of this classic Billy Wilder film where every twisting turn of the boulevard and Norma Desmond's mind is felt banging in the viewer's stomach. William Holden is a starving writer who doesn't want to return the rented car and finds a twisting turn on his own destiny as he hides inside the mysteriously overgrown driveway off the twisted Bel Air area of the Los Angeles suburbs in order to hide from the men after him. He's in for more than he bargained for when he rings the doorbell of the dilapidated estate (shades of Grey Gardens) and finds a funeral for a chimpanzee going on. If the sight of dour butler Erich Von Stroheim isn't enough to get him to turn around and rush out of there, the sun-glassed older lady who mistakes him for an undertaker should be. But Gillis, an obvious expert in Hollywood History 101, instantly recognizes her. She's Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a silent movie star whose career ended years before, lost in memories of Valentino and Chaplin, and certainly not in tuned with 1950 Hollywood.

Author: 7 October 1999
Review: One of the great scary movies
Review_Url: I first saw this movie last year ('98) around the Christmas season. It may not have been the best time of year to see it (Halloween would have best) but it was still worth a look either time. I love Gloria Swanson's scary, almost evil plot to take over William Holden's mind and making him her "property". You feel there is a chance he and Nancy Olsen's character will be able to get away from her and live their lives in peace together but the story is a tragedy so there has to be some disappointments. Norma (Swanson) refuses to let Joe (Holden) go but he still persists and she kills him. The audience tends to pity Norma for losing her career in the movies and for desperately trying to hold on to it (she surrounds herself with old publicity pictures of herself for comfort) even though it's dead and has no chance of redemption. After killing Holden, she practically becomes oblivious to the deed and suffocates herself into believing, "I am the greatest star there ever was". It is a great American classic. The greatest scary movie ever made!

Author: 6 January 2003
Review_Url: This is a Wilder classic, and that's saying a lot.

Author: 9 March 2000
Review_Url: Though Sunset Boulevard IS an actual place in Hollywood, I've often wondered since seeing one of the true gems of the 1950's (the decade of the Big Lie, as I like to call it) if maybe Wilder and Co. were aiming for metaphor as well. Think about it: if Norma Desmond's life isn't in it's final stages by the time her boytoy pops up on her doorstep, then we may as well agree with her apparent belief that she's never going to die. Max (played by silent era film giant Erich Von Stronheim; when he talks of the three great silent directors, all they did was change the name for his role), who discovered, married, and now serves Norma passed his high noon in films long before. Then there's William Holden, who doesn't realize that his life and career are entering the last stages, right up until the fatal bullets hit him from behind (do you honestly think that he could tell this story so objectively until then?).

Author: 11 March 2011
Review_Url: From Golden Globe winning, and Oscar nominated director Bill Wilder (The Seven Year Itch, Some Like It Hot, The Apartment), this was a film I had heard about for a few year, and being in the book 1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die I definitely wanted to see it. Basically set in the 1950's Hollywood, movie screenplay writer Joe C. Gillis (Oscar nominated William Holden) narrates the story going to flashback that leads up to the murder seen at the beginning. Joe is struggling to get his work sold to any studios and has debts, and one night he ends up with his car getting a flat tyre and at the mansion of a former silent movie star on Sunset Boulevard. Norma Desmond (Golden Globe winning, and Oscar nominated Gloria Swanson) lives alone with butler and driver Max Von Mayerling (Oscar and Golden Globe nominated Erich Von Stroheim), and has been doing so for many years since losing her popularity, becoming deluded and demented since, believing that one day she could return to the industry. Max being her ex-husband and former director who still has feelings for her is very protective of Norma, but she wants Joe to move in to the mansion to write a new screenplay for her to make her comeback, and in the process her becomes her lover and gigolo. Even though he is getting paid for doing this, he slowly starts feeling trapped, and seeking friendship he leaves one night to see Artie Green (Jack Webb), and he bumps into studio reader Betty Schaefer (Oscar nominated Nancy Olson). They quickly become attracted to each other, but Joe still returns Norma feeling some very warped sense of loyalty to the old actress, of course he still meets up with Betty to help her with her own script idea. By the time it seems the couple have fallen in love, Norma finds out and feels extremely jealous, she tries to sabotage whatever they have together. In the end Joe makes the hasty decision to threaten to leave the mansion, and that is when Norma really loses her mind and shoots him dead, so he has been narrating from beyond the grave, and with the press showing up about the murder her demented mind of fantasy thinks that she has made her longed after comeback. Also starring Fred Clark as Sheldrake, Lloyd Gough as Morino, The Ten Commandments director Cecil B. DeMille, Hedda Hopper, Anna Q. Nilsson, H.B. Warner, Ray Evans, Jay Livingston and Sherlock Junior silent star Buster Keaton. Mostly all films about Hollywood before this were jolly and often musical, but this was the first to really show the cynicism and darker side, with fantastic acting, a witty script, and all the usual traits and tricks I have come to expect from a great film noir, a brilliant satirical drama. It won the Oscars for Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Best Music for Franz Waxman and Best Writing, Story and Screenplay, and it was nominated for Best Cinematography, Best Film Editing and Best Picture, and it won the Golden Globes for Best Motion Picture - Drama and Best Motion Picture Score, and it was nominated for Best Cinematography and Best Screenplay. "I am big! It's the pictures that got small" was number 24, and "All right, Mr. DeMille, I'm ready for my close-up." Number 7 on 100 Years, 100 Quotes, the film was number 16 on 100 Years of Film Scores, it was 52 on The 100 Greatest Films, it was number 16 on 100 Years, 100 Greatest Movies and it was number 12 on 100 Years, 100 Movies. Very good!

Author: 8 June 2021
Review_Url: Masterpiece. Norma Desmond is without a doubt, one of cinemas greatest and landmark characters. This couldn't have been made at a better time, 1950, like are you kidding me? The middle of the century and one of the first turns of cinema into the modern age? Just such a special film.

Author: 7 November 2011
Review: Unique and Fascinating View of Hollywood! Eery and Unnerving!
Review_Url: My father introduced me to this film when I was quite young and I never forgot it. He was clearly impressed with this film and I always respected his judgment when it came to assessing a good film. This film is beyond good. It is unbelievably good. There are so many reviews of this film there is no point for me to add to the generous accolades given by many reviewers. If you read a positive review accept it! If negative, reject it! This is one of the most amazing films ever made. Gripping to the end, this cinematic experience is one of the most exciting rides you will ever take. Gloria Swanson is strangely, eerily and inexplicably sexual and sexy in her role as Norma Desmond. I wonder if she knew what was going on when they made this film? And Erich Von Stroheim as Max Von Meyerling "You see, I was her first husband"...Wipe your feet"..."Gordon Cole"... is a frightening portrayal of death come to life which is masterfully rendered on screen. William Holden is perfect in his role as a broken down hack with no future who is dependent on the whims of a mentally deranged older woman. A great psychological thriller! Just see the film and buy to own! You will want to see this one more than once. Great for Halloween!

Author: 6 December 2014

Author: 27 February 2015
Review_Url: I didn't enjoy watching this film too much, but it was a good change from today's crude, violent filled film. Not to say that it's not a good movie. The plot is extremely well written in my opinion. Norma Desmond, a silent film star trying to continue her career with the new sound films. This film gave me an idea of what the film business was like in the 1950's. It also makes me think and appreciate how far film has come today. Often I pass off a high speed chase or a battle scene in movie and forget how much time and effort has gone into it. Back to Sunset Blvd... The relationship between Norma and Joe is very interesting to watch unfold. Norma can't let go, and all Joe wants to do is be free from Norma and live his life the way he wants to. Author: 19 January 2008
Review: Hammy as Hell, But Has Its Moments
Review_Url: Sorry, I have to align myself with those few other reviewers who found the movie, well, trite. Not that it didn't have its moments -- that particularly riveting scene, for instance, where Norma sits in DeMille's chair and a stagehand acquaintance puts a spotlight on her and people begin crowding around her, how spooky can you get? But by and large, Gloria Swanson hams up her lines to the point where she becomes a TV skit caricature (only this skit goes on way too long), Holden runs his lines off too fast, and von Stroheim mumbles all his lines indifferently (I picture him saying to himself, "Here I am, the genius who directed 'Greed', and what am I doing today??"). Let's face it, folks, this is the kind of claptrap that made the revolution in film-making some 20 years later so necessary, films like "The French Connection" and "Raiders of the Lost Ark" sweeping away the cobwebs of crass melodramas like "Sunset Boulevard" and never looking back. Tell me I'm wrong.

Author: 23 March 2022
Review_Url: SUNSET BOULEVARD (1950) is a film that I discovered in my youth that has always stuck with me. And it's just as powerful, emotional, and memorable over 70 years after it came out in theaters. THE ultimate scathing indictment and essay on the cold, ruthless nature of Hollywood. The film was nominated for 11 Oscars, won 3, and should have won more, but especially Gloria Swanson, who was nominated Best Actress, should have won. This is probably one of the top 10 performances in history that didn't win an Oscar. And her competition wasn't exactly shabby as she was up against dual All About Eve threats Bette Davis and Anne Baxter, as well as Eleanor Parker for Caged, and the actual winner Judy Holliday for Born Yesterday. The popular take it should have come down to Swanson and Davis, but that Baxter took votes that might have gone to both of those ladies, so that Holliday managed to steal the award due to the split voting. No matter, Swanson is the one who should have won the gold. Her performance is by far one of the most fascinating and unforgettable in film history.

Author: 4 June 2020
Review: Gloria Swanson Gives the Performance of the Century
Review_Url: Exactly in the middle of the 20th century, Gloria Swanson delivered one of the best performances in film history. I have seen this movie countless times, but I can always find something new to admire. Watching it as an old person is very different from watching it young when I thought Swanson's portrayal of Norma Desmond was camp; now it seems like pure pathos. The style of the film is noir, melodramatic and eerily gothic, but Swanson's best scenes are not only the classic descending the staircase or snapping "I am big; it's the pictures that got small." The scene in which she begs Joe (William Holden) to love her is heartbreaking. I used to feel a bit sorry for Joe, bamboozled as he was into her trap; not so now. Holden's character is a liar and an absolute cad. Even when he seems to genuinely care for her after the suicide attempt, he is really caring only for himself. When the movie was released in 1950 the idea of a woman of 50--who we are told has been washed up for the previous 20 years, which means she must have been through at 30-- falling for a man half her age must have been shocking. But it really does tell the story of how Hollywood treated its great leading ladies. No such revulsion for the male matinee idols who regularly played love scenes with girls half their age. In Sunset Boulevard, we are told in so many scenes that Joe was practically nauseated by the idea of making love to her, but he is such a user that he continues to feed her delusions. It is also interesting to note that we are never shown a sexual scene, certainly not one of those deep kisses that Humphrey Bogart and Gary Cooper regularly planted on actresses who should have been playing their daughters. Is Sunset Boulevard over the top? You bet, way over, and I cannot get enough of it.

Author: 22 October 2003
Review: Wilder's best, Holden's best, one of the best.
Review_Url: Billy Wilder's classic SUNSET BLVD. is probably Hollywood's best self-loathing look at itself. William Holden is great as a struggling screenwriter running from his creditors who encounters has-been silent film star Gloria Swanson (who is pretty much playing herself in the guise of Norma Desmond). Her tragic character and her decaying palace of a home are very heavy and very dark, the kind of thing that only a great comedy directer like Billy Wilder could give us. Erich Von Strohiem appears as Swanson's butler who was a silent film director (as the actor was in real life). The truth of these performances is part of what makes the film's statement about Hollywood so delightfully bitter. Watching this film will prove to anyone that the hype and reputation are entirely justified. The film viewer of today can appreciate the connection to David Lynch's supposed homage MULHOLLAND DR. about another dark tale associated with another L.A. street. See both films, but see this one first.

Author: 5 September 2005
Review: After A Decade, It Seems Better Than Ever
Review_Url: Deservedly a classic of American movies. It holds up in spite o the ongoing parodies on the Carol Burnett Show, which sank some lesser movies. (Maybe they were homages as well as parodies.) A very dark movie, with everything right ion place. Holden is excellent, though at times his voice-over narration is a little arch. Swanson is fascinating. (What could this possibly have been like with Wilder's original choices -- Mae West for Norma and Montgomery Clift? Clift would have been good but West, much as I love her, would have sunk it.) Holden's interest in Nancy Olson has never quite made sense to me. She is attractive and appealing but her wholesomeness breaks the mood. That may have been the writer and director's intention. If so, I'd call it misguided. But who am I? Bill Wilder is one of the finest directors this country has ever known and I do not propose to second-guess him.

Author: 9 December 2002

Author: 8 June 2019
Review_Url: Joe Gillis (William Holden) is a Hollywood writer struggling to find work and pay off his debts. He unintentionally ends up parking in the driveway of a dilapidated mansion owned by Norman Desmond (Gloria Swanson), a mostly forgotten movie star of the silent era. Joe has writing skills and lacks money; Norma has loads of money but needs a writer to help her with a screenplay that she intends for her comeback. Author: 9 September 2013
Review: A masterpiece of a character study
Review_Url: Sunset Boulevard is a 1950 film about Joe Gillis (William Holden), an unsuccessful screenwriter, and his time with Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), an old silent film star who is still completely obsessed with herself. The film begins in a peculiar way. It is narrated by the character of Joe Gillis and starts off by showing his body in a pool, we know he dies from the start. This is actually my only flaw with the entire film, although it is very minor. I thought it would have made for an interesting twist if we didn't know, but I could be wrong and the fact that we know the entire time may have helped the film rather than hindered it. Gloria Swanson is the true star of this film. As William Holden's character has no real money left, he eventually stumbles upon Norma Desmond's home. He stays with her for the duration of the film as she gradually delves into disillusionments, self-obsession, shallowness, and pure insanity about her previous film career.

Author: 23 December 2001
Review: Old but still a pretty good watch.
Review_Url: Wilder's Oscar winning noir psychodrama  "Sunset Blvd" pales in comparison with many middle tier films of today in spite of being revered as a classic. In keeping with the public's appetite of its time, "Sunset..." is melodramatic, fraught with overacting, and promotes a plot which raises more questions than it answers all in the interest of entertaining a movie going public hungry for escape from the memories of global war and the realities of reconstruction. Telling of a reluctant gigolo and hack screenwriter who is kept by a has-been Hollywood silent screen star on the verge of madness, the film is rendered like a jig-saw puzzle with characters distorted as necessary to make them fit the desired end result. In spite of its shortcomings in light of present day cinematic capability and technology, "Sunset..." is an interesting watch and a durable film.  As with another Wilder film, "Sabrina", a contemporary remake could please Hollywood exec's as well as the public at large.

Author: 15 September 1998

Author: 1 July 2010
Review: The harsh reality behind the celluloid screen....
Review_Url: The life of a movie star is something very volatile and strange.Their glam and fame make peoples love them,when they are young and at the peak of their career peoples admire their beauty and talent,we call them star because they shines among the billions like a star.But in reality they don't have the life time like a star,in fact celebrity status is more like a air bubble,so much fragile and thin which doesn't stay forever floating in the air,as the time passes it just need a little push of fate and in few moments they became past and no one remember them.But they never overcome their life style which is full of glamor and fame,they just don't want to believe that their days of repute are over,they always live in their past, unaware of their present and uncertain about their future.This is the dark and naked truth about the cruel world of Cinema that no body cares about a fading star not even their audience,a movie star is nothing more than a joker in the circus for an audience.whether it is Hollywood or any other place the story is same.Sunset Boulevard is a haunting tragedy and hard-hitting satire that make us familiar with this dark side of Film Industry,the harsh reality of a movie star's life.

Author: 23 August 2021
Review_Url: Norma Desmond is the epitome of the Hollywood has-been: a narcissistic, privilege, histrionic old woman who is stuck in the past, failing to realise the world has moved on without her. The casting of Gloria Swanson is perfect, both in terms of her insanely flourishing performance and the meta aspect of her career. Her environment reflects her own mental state - unkempt, luxurious and isolated, existing in solitude and maintained only by the most superficial facade of fandom. It is the chance appearance of Joe Gillis that upsets all of this, triggering Norma's need for affection and conflicting with Joe's career desires. This ensnares the characters in a claustrophobic dilemma that grips them until it is resolved through the peak of sheer insanity. This nightmare scenario is fuelled mainly by the expert acting that brings the anguish to life.

Author: 28 May 2002
Review: The dark side of Hollywood in glorious black-and-white
Review_Url: This picture takes the happily-ever-after myth of Hollywood stardom and shatters it for good.  When talking pictures became the standard virtually overnight, the big studios turned their collective backs on most of the silent icons that had helped build them.  This film offers a frequently sympathetic view of the descent of one of these icons into despair and madness - and for silent film buffs, offers a rare opportunity to see the likes of Anna Q. Nilsson and Buster Keaton in speaking cameos.  Billy Wilder's genius as a director is evident in the way that the very adult relationships among the principal characters are conveyed perfectly, under the yoke of the Hays Code, without the use of nudity or profanity

Author: 22 December 2020
Review_Url: About to lose his car because of debt, scriptwriter Joe finds himself in an old mansion while escaping with his car. After hiding his car, the butler calls him inside. Not understanding what happened, Joe sees a dead chimpanzee and a woman upstairs. Joe says there is a misunderstanding, and the woman learns that he is a screenwriter. Norma Desmond, the former silent movie star, offers her money to help her with the script. Joe agrees to pay off his debts, and the woman has the butler prepare the room above the garage for him to stay. When he wakes up, he sees that his belongings have been brought from his house, and even though he gets angry, the woman convinces him. The butler Max is actually her first husband, and the melancholic woman sends fan letters home to feel good, and at the same time the man is the director who made her famous. Joe leaves home when the woman gets close to him on Christmas night and goes to his friend's party. They decide to work on one of their scenarios with his friend's wife. Norma cut her wrists when she left. Joe treats him well and sneaks out of the house at night, writing a script with the woman. They then go to Paramount studios to see the director for whom he sent the script. People are nice to the woman, but the director didn't like the script and the reason they called her butler is to use the woman's old car in a movie. Upon jealousy, he calls Betty and upon hearing this, Joe tells Betty to come to the mansion on the phone and tells the woman everything. After sending the woman, the man leaves the gifts and packs her belongings. Seeing this, Norma shoots the man at the exit and the man falls into the pool and dies. When the cameras and the police arrived, the woman completely lost her mind. She thinks the cameras have come for the movie and she starts acting. Max is sad that he could not protect the woman in the dream world he created.

Author: 17 June 2008
Review: A haunting, eerie and amazingly true look at Hollywood! One of the best films ever made
Review_Url: Perhaps the best film ever made, 'Sunset Blvd' follows the story of lonely and struggling writer Joe Gillis (William Holden) who is thrown into a web of romance and feuds with aging silent actress Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) and her creepy butler Max Von Mayerling (Erich Von Stroheim) when he accidentally stumbles across Norma's mansion when he uses her garage for his car so it doesn't get taken. Norma will do anything for him, and she also truly believes she is still famous even though people barely remember her and she can make a comeback to Hollywood. But Joe knows all to better and wants to escape her odd, aging and treacherous ways. He meets Betty Schaefer (Nancy Olson) and begins writing a script with her-and perhaps even falling in love. This sets off Norma who will stop at nothing to be in the limelight, get Joe and make pictures again...even if it means murder. An intelligent look at Hollywood with amazing performances and one of the best scripts. The use of the black and white color makes a grim and eerie look of the film, which helps pull the viewer in. A fascinating thing about the film is that while the story is fictional it somewhat holds true to Gloria Swanson, even at one point viewing a film of hers that ruined her career! A truly haunting and memorable look at the desperate and true side of Hollywood. 10/10

Author: 14 January 2022
Review: Wilder's Tale About Delusion and Fame!
Review_Url:
"There's nothing else. Just us, and the cameras, and those wonderful people out there in the dark. All right, Mr. De Mille, I'm ready for my closeup."
These are the painful words from aging actress Norma Desmond as she grapples with fame right after she committed a murder. This phrase is one of the most memorable phrases in cinema's history. Billy Wilder has a knack of making such endings in his movies as evidenced by Some Like It Hot. Sunset Blvd. Is one of the best movies about Hollywood. It tackles a very relevant topic as it deals with fame and what happens when fame run its course. The movie is every bit of a film-noir as it is a comedy. Just like Wilder did with Double Indemnity, he created a movie that thrills at nearly every turn and the relationship between William Holden and Gloria Swanson keeps coming and grabbing you until the shocking ending. You can also classify the movie as a black comedy. Personally, I did not have any belly rolls but rather uncomfortable giggles which is by design. The pet monkey funeral sequence is just an example of one that illicit such giggles. Regardless of the genre, the movie is about as good as it can be. It is a surefire classic and one that cements Billy Wilder's as cinema's most impressive director.

Author: 4 May 2010
Review: a very strange film noir film
Review_Url: I Thought that overall sunset blvd was a good movie. I did find it very hard to deal with Gloria Swanson even though she played a magnificent role and casting her was perfect for the role she had. You could tell she was a silence film actress because you could see how she used expressions and looks to portray just how she was feeling or dealing with things. This is what made it very hard for me to deal with this women. I felt the director did appropriate job of selecting a cast that met the demands of the movie including Nancy Olsen who plays the woman who gets William Holdens mojo for writing back. The score and dark ominous lighting did a amazing job of portraying just how dark a road William holden's character was moving down the line and just how far and extreme it might get to escape it. This is why the beginning scene which happens to be the last scene sets off a great example of what can happen in life if you just accept things and let people start to run your life. Wiliam Holden knew there was no escaping the dark, scary tones of what Gloria Swanson's life had become because without her he truly had nothing. Overall, this movie was brilliant and strange while keeping you on the edge of your seat to see what will happen to "Joe Gillis" next.

Author: 21 September 2020
Review_Url: This film begins with a writer in Hollywood by the name of "Joe Gillis" (William Holden) who is having difficulty selling any of his work and as a result he is down on his luck and out of money. As luck would have it, however, while trying to elude some men attempting to repossess his automobile a flat tire causes him to drive into what he thinks is an abandoned mansion on Sunset Boulevard. Once there he is met by an elderly man named "Max Von Mayerling" (Erich von Stroheim) who motions for him to come into the house as the owner wishes to see immediately. It's then that he meets a former silent movie actress by the name of "Norma Desmond" (Gloria Swanson) who mistakes him for a funeral director called upon to bury a pet. Once the error is corrected she informs him that she has a script for a movie she has been working on and would like his professional opinion on it as she is planning on returning to the movie business to reclaim her former glory. Although he accepts her eventual offer of employment what Joe doesn't tell her is that the film industry has long since evolved and she simply doesn't have the talent necessary for such a return. What Joe doesn't understand is the danger associated with her mental and emotional instability during this particular time. Now rather than reveal any more I will just say that this was an entertaining drama which benefited from good performances by all involved. I especially like the haunting ending which Gloria Swanson delivered with such eerie precision and I recommend it for those interested in a film of this type. Above average.

Author: 1 September 2015
Review_Url: Sunset Boulevard (1950): Dir: Billy Wilder / Cast: William Holden, Gloria Swanson, Erich von Stroheim, Nancy Olson, Cecil B. DeMille: Absolute masterpiece representing a place where dreams happened for one Gloria Swanson who was a big silent star but now her fame is fading and she dreams her life away with private screenings of her own films. Narrated by William Holden who is sheltered at her mansion in return for a screenplay that will resurrect her. Intriguing setup rich in dialogue and plot turns that result in the ultimate revelation in the conclusion. Billy Wilder does an excellent job at presenting ill fate Hollywood careers due to technology. Wilder previously made an entirely different film called Double Indemnity and both share a common theme of dominating femme figure. Swanson delivers a riveting performance of a woman illusion to total madness. Holden feels his talent trapped and seeks escape through an outside project. Erich von Stroheim is the ex-husband who lives to revive her past. He will be instrumental in assisting her concluding performance and famous last words. Nancy Olson plays a screenwriter unable to unlock Holden's thoughts. She is engaged yet will face Holden's forced lifestyle in blunt terms. Great cameo performances by film personalities portraying themselves, including famed director Cecil B. DeMille. It is the dark side of show business where stars flicker no more. Score: 10 / 10

Author: 26 September 2017
Review: I thought I was in for a real treat
Review_Url: As I unwrapped my Blu-ray to re-watch this old favourite I thought I was in for a real treat. Perhaps I should not have watched it so soon after seeing Aronofsky's mother! That film is full of terrifying emotions and selfish actions supposedly in the service of selflessness. And here, something not altogether different but so mannered, so other worldly. The beginning is great, all mystery and ambiguity, the scene where we visit Paramount Studios and meet the real Cecil B DeMille directing while a spotlight is turned upon our crazy heroine is fantastic. But so much of this is mundane and repetitive. Review: 'Sunset Boulevard' is one of the greatest movies you'll ever see.
Review_Url: Los Angeles setting. Wry, reflective narration. Cutting dialogue, biting and sometimes grim or morbid humor, timeless cultural references. Above all: characters with huge personality; increasingly tangled relationships and circumstances; a course of events that slowly spirals out beyond manageability. This is a film noir, alright, and more than that, it's unquestionably one of the definitive pictures of the genre. Yet these are just broad descriptive terms for the nutritious substance of the movie - the details are the garnish, the spices, that add tremendous flavor. And, oh, how delicious it is. The production design and art direction are exemplary, filling every scene with delightful sights and sounds at every corner. The costume design, hair and makeup work, and above all set design and decoration are wonderfully fetching, a real treat for the eyes. The lines given to star William Holden for the protagonist's narration are brilliant in their sharp wit, and nigh poetic vocabulary and arrangement, and Holden delivers each with a dark panache that amounts to verbal instant gratification. And whatever the mood of a given scene, so it is for much of the dialogue at large, both Holden's, and Gloria Swanson's, and Erich von Stroheim's, and everyone's. In fact: it's one matter to see a feature described as one of the best movies ever made, but to watch it for oneself and confirm that truth is an altogether fabulous experience. Seventy years of acclaim do not lie - 'Sunset Boulevard' is an incredible, essential film.

Author: 2 October 2019
Review_Url: 'Sunset Blvd. (1950)', a veritable cinematic classic, is surprisingly meta, comprised almost entirely of interlaced 'Easter eggs' which take the form of 'art imitating life', celebrity cameos and, of course, movie references. This 'self-eating snake' nature is perhaps appropriate considering that the piece is still one of the best, most in-depth insights into - and a near damnation of - Hollywood, specifically 'old Hollywood'. It's also a keen portrayal of a sad kind of self-obsession usually associated with famous artists, one that the person often clings to beyond all hope primarily because their personality is so intrinsically tied to it. This self-perpetuating cycle of defining one's worth by how much strangers 'admire' them is certainly toxic and is, quite boldly, on full display. Ultimately, the picture is rather bleak, showcasing how society often enables dangerous behaviour by awarding it with their attention. The themes I've mentioned would be enough to float an entire flick but this one has even more still. It looks at money, financial security, loneliness, emasculation, creativity, mental illness and attention-seeking behaviour. It's remarkably interesting. It's also consistently entertaining, styled with a lavish 'noir' aesthetic that paints every frame, along with the usually decrepit things within them, in a beautiful black-and-white hue that somehow has a real thematic resonance in and of itself. The purposefully heavy-handed, hard-boiled but often flowery narration adds to the narrative's eerily enigmatic nature. The story is seemingly straight-forward, yet it's also oddly bizarre in the best way possible. Everything just feels like it's on top-form, here. The direction uses dazzling camera-work to invigorate the dialogue-based plot, beginning with an absolutely brilliant one-shot title-sequence and otherwise featuring its lion's share of inventive angles (the under-water shot is a real highlight and a proper bit of technical wizardry, too). The performances perfectly walk the line of realism and 'showbiz', with the balance being palpably different for each character. Swanson's Norma Desmond almost feels like she's acting in a silent movie, oozing intensity from every facial feature, whereas Holden's Joe Gillis slowly transitions from a 'Golden era' star to a paranoid, under-the-thumb man who thinks he's trapped with some sort of 'B-movie' monster and may actually like it. Tying everything together is this 'behind-the-scenes' feel. You're being taken on a tour of the very thing that produces pictures like this and people like Desmond. The more you read about it after the fact, the more you realise that it must've been shot through some sort of mirror. It may be a fictional tale, but it resembles reality in more ways than it doesn't and sometimes simply presents it to you (or a version of it, at least). Its haunting end is one of the most famous of all time but the whole affair is worthy of that status. It's an ahead-of-its-time experience that's as enjoyable as it impressive. As I said, it's a classic. 8/10

Review_Url: Sunset Boulevard from 1950 is a magnificently twisted Film Noir. Norma Desmond was a once extremely famous Hollywood Actress. Everyone knew who she was, loved her films and her mind absolutely adored her. What Norma doesn't realize is that she has been out of the spotlight for a longtime. She has been hiding away in her once gorgeous home, holding on to what she once was. Her house is very reflective of what she herself had become over the years. The house hadn't received much attention and in turn has become dull and un-groomed; Norma Desmond did the same. Joe Gillis is a screenwriter that has also been struggling with his career. He manages to fall in to Norma's world, and in the end shatters it. Joe agrees to help Norma with her comeback film, but in the process realizes that nobody is waiting to see it. Norma's mental state isn't always logical, but her character makes you feel for her. She was once this beautiful actress that was on top of the film world; now she's lucky if she is a distant memory. This is a dark film that shows what fame can do to a person. Norma seems as though she is stuck in the spotlight and doesn't know how to live life otherwise. Author: 6 January 2023
Review_Url: "Gillis" (William Holden) is a down-at-heel script writer who is struggling to keep his head above water. Not having had any successes for a while, his car is about to be repossessed and his erstwhile boss "Sheldrake" (Fred Clark) has nothing for him. On the run from the pursuing repo men, he turns his car into the drive of a decaying old mansion. Hiding his car in the garage, he is mistaken by the house's owner for an undertaker - she has a small matter that needs attending too! Realising her error she demands he leave, but not before he mentions what he does for a living. She has a script. Hundreds of pages of script - and she offers him a job, champagne and caviar if he will edit and refine it so "Norma Desmond" (Gloria Swanson), a retired former silent movie star, can present it to her favourite director Cecil B DeMille and restart her glorious career. Initially just seeing dollar signs, he agrees and what now ensues is a masterfully crafted story of love, dependency, ambition and delusion in which Swanson absolutely shines. It's clear to us from the outset that her grasp on reality is somewhat limited, and but for her dedicated factotum "Max" (Erich von Stroheim) she might well have fallen victim to her own depression many years ago. Holden is also on solid form here, his initial selfishness starts to morph into something more, he begins to care for this woman whose head is increasingly in the clouds, and upon whom she is becoming more reliant. The dialogue is delivered via a mix of Holden's quite honest narrative and the conversations between the characters delivering some of the best lines in cinema - "I'm still big - it's the world that's got smaller!". The mental decline and instability of "Desmond" is expertly displayed here by a star who new a thing or two herself about the silent film scene, and who brings her facial expressions, her mannerisms and her generally star-studded demeanour to bear really effectively as the audience gradually realise that nothing here is going to pan out as it seems - or as anyone wants. Von Stroheim underplays his supporting role with aplomb and though I didn't really love the sub-plot with Nancy Olson's "Betty Schaefer" - it took away from the intensity of the main storyline - it did to serve to illustrate just how powerful jealousy can be. This is a super film, that still captivates on a big screen and is really well worth sitting down to watch.,

Review_Url: Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond in Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard (1950) is one of Paramount's biggest stars. The film's argument about the bad old days of Hollywood is more complicated than that, as the studio system was starting to crumble and the beginnings of the industry were coming back to haunt it. Desmond's pride mocks the fall of Hollywood just as it was teetering, rocked by the antitrust laws, the coming of TV and the communist witch-hunts. Desmond lives in a dusty seclusion on Sunset Boulevard with her butler Max, until a young screenwriter, Joe Gillis (William Holden), stumbles across her house and ensnares him to become her script editor and lover. Gillis initially feels pity for Desmond and compares her house to Miss Havisham, who has been rejected. Desmond is deluded about her fame and importance to the modern movie industry, while Gillis and his young pals live cheaply and crack wise about the industry. They are cynical and smart enough not to be fooled by it. The crumbling Hollywood of Sunset Boulevard is built on the silent era, with Betty's family being a cinema dynasty due to her stunt work for Pearl White. Norma Desmond made Paramount Studios a success, not the other way around. The faltering movie business was built on stronger, more ambitious grounds than it occupied in 1950. Norma Desmond still causes a ripple of excitement when she enters the soundstage, but the pictures that got small. Swanson made a successful transition into the talkies and then went on to be a successful business woman, remaining a very public figure. She first appeared on film as a teenager in 1914 and lived until she was 84. The most telling difference between Desmond and Swanson is that Swanson left Paramount to sign with United Artists and take control of her own career. She made films and career choices that marked her out as a modern woman, frank by the standards of the day about sexuality and married life. Her first hits were brisk sex comedies directed by DeMille such as Don't Change Your Husband (1919) and Male and Female (1919). By 1928 she was courting controversy with her passion project Sadie Thompson (1928), a steamy Somerset Maugham adaptation directed by Raoul Walsh.

Review: As fine as film noir gets!
Review_Url: How do you get more culturally meta with film than by making a film noir set inside the Hollywood landscape itself? Well, Sunset Boulevard answers that non-specific question in a beautiful fashion and then some by telling a story about 'delusions of grandeur' and how time's passage can become an unforgiving beast for movie stars still gloating about their 'good old days'. Norma Desmond is an out-of-touch actress who's refused to come to terms with, or accept, reality. She happens to come across struggling screenwriter Joe Gillis escaping from the men who lent him his car. After skidding onto the former star's driveway by coincidence, Joe's life takes one dark turn after another: and the film's look into career realism as well as its equally potent career naivety (even if the person it's coming from has more experience in real life). Norma is one of cinema's prettiest faces embodying the idea of tragedy and aged celebrity-status.

Author: 28 January 2015
Review: The very definition of a classic.
Review_Url: In an age when cinema generally succumbed to the tropes and clichés to which audiences were mechanically accustomed as a means for quicker cash, what better way to set the precedent of new and original storytelling as an art form than Billy Wilder's introduction to the 1950s, Sunset Boulevard - a film that explores excitingly unfamiliar territory while simultaneously presenting itself as a meta commentary of such transformation in the motion picture industry. A master of genre versatility, Wilder makes significant alterations to film noir with the addition of a light comedic backdrop, still managing to close on a note of poignancy that lingers in the mind, cementing the film as a landmark in movie history.

Author: 29 July 2018
Review: I AM big. It's the pictures that got small.
Review_Url: A dead man narrates Sunset Boulevard, eager to tell us his version of the events, the cold, hard facts, before they are distorted and blown out of proportion by the radio and television screen. Joe Gillis is a writer, and naturally wants his story to retain its integrity. Wilder gives us a witty snapshot of that idea disappearing in a puff of smoke early in the film, where Joe pitches his baseball script to an producer in a dinghy little office. Firstly it's openly mocked by a script reader (the demure yet snappy Nancy Olson) who wants something grandiose and with a message. "You'd have turned down Gone with the Wind!" splutters Joe in exasperation. "No, that was me," remarks the producer with resignation. Almost absent-mindedly whilst lounging on the couch, he twists Joe's story into an all-female spectacle with musical interludes, with the screen credit the only remaining vestige of the initial premise. And when Joe pleas for a personal loan, he launches into a spiel about his own spiralling debts that Wilder quickly cuts away from. There's no need for semantics; he's hemorrhaging money, like most of Hollywood, where original ideas are sparse and basic plots are organised by numbers and letters.

Review_Url: Man, sure seems like people love to write mini-books on this site about Sunset Blvd. I'll try to keep my opinion concise and to the point. The forgotten movie star living in a dilapidated, spooky mansion off Sunset Blvd. is a terrific setting. Great casting abounds with Gloria Swanson and hottie William Holden, and the strange friends each of them have. But for me, this movie falls apart every time they pull away from Gloria to concentrate on Joe and Betty's budding romance. Why devote so much screen time to a bland character, Betty Schaefer, struggling to write a who cares script called "Dark Windows" or whatever it's called, when we could be spending more time with faded, kooky Norma Desmond in her scary house with Max? Face it, no body writes volumes about Nancy Olson's character do they? We all know who makes this movie great, and it ain't her. Author: 26 December 2005
Review: Like Norma Desmond this film has not aged well but still packs a wallop
Review_Url: Not quite the shocker it was in 1950, "Sunset Blvd." still packs a wallop. For most director/writers "Sunset Blvd." would have been the height of their careers, their masterpiece, but for multi-talented Billy Wilder there were better pictures. "Double indemnity," "The Apartment," "Some Like It Hot," and two highly underrated films "Ace in the Hole" and "One, Two, Three" are better written than "Sunset Blvd." Take off the tinsel and the viewer will find some cracks in "Sunset Blvd." One distraction is the narration by the body floating in the swimming pool. There's a cliché that dead men tell no tales. Well, a dead man tells one hell of a tale in this film. The movie takes forever to get to the essence of the story. It gets better and better as the movie progresses until it explodes at the end. The best scene in the whole film is the last scene when Norma Desmond gives what amounts to a soliloquy for the newsreel cameras.

Review_Url: The most admirable thing about this Billy Wilder masterpiece is the courage it took to make this film. 1950 is exactly in the middle between the self-imposed production code and the anti-American pogroms. Both take the point of view of the ambitions and the frustrations of leading ladies that lived long enough to witness their fading. Both were nominated for best film. All About Eve, perhaps because it was more direct and less metaphorical about its subject manner, won the day. It is no doubt a good film but today we recognise Sunset as the superior work.

DeMille to direct but had a terrible script. Author: 2 September 2010
Review: A ruthless film about the flip side of the Hollywood glamor
Review_Url: Billy Wilder, born in Austria-Hungary built himself a huge reputation during 1940's-60's in Hollywood. He's is best known for his comedies with Marilyn Monroe (Some Like It Hot, The Seven Year Itch), but his other films haven't remained in the shadows either. In 1944 he directed his film-noir masterpiece Double Indemnity, which became a big inspiration for many directors. In addition to these films Billy Wilder's trade mark is probably his own unique satire, best seen in One Two Three!, A Foreign Affair and of course in Sunset Blvd. In 1950 Billy Wilder was already at the top of his career, he produced his films himself and therefore had much more artistic freedom. This freedom allowed him to make a different kind of film with the screenwriter, Charles Brackett. Sunset Blvd. was no one night wonder, it took two years to finish it and the most time went to the writing. Brackett has told that someone suggested that they should make a film about a forgotten silent-era actress, who meets a desperate writer. They casted Gloria Swanson (who actually was one of the biggest silent-era starts) to play the role of Norma Desmond, a forgotten star.

Author: 29 January 2006
Review: Gloria Swanson is braver than you . . .
Review_Url: . . . and, no question, braver than I'll ever be. Now that 75 is the new 50, it's hard for us to imagine the sheer moxie -- and the steep risk of career-poisoning mockery -- put into play in 1949 when a 50-year-old actress long past her glamor-drenched prime became Norma Desmond, the only living soul who doesn't know her day is done and her sex appeal is long gone. I can't think of a precedent for a woman taking on such a perilous role in a serious movie, and I doubt that any of today's maturing -- OK, aging -- woman stars would do it on a dare, let alone agree to play side-by-side with film clips from their glory days. There are a few better films and a handful of better performances, but nobody ever undressed her own persona on screen with more daring and to better effect than Miss Swanson. Ten stars and a medal of valor.

Author: 10 May 2010
Review_Url: This film was suspenseful but at times did seem to drag on. At the start of the film the viewer is introduced to the main character and the narrator of the film, floating dead in a pool. Right off the bat the audience is waiting for his demise during the whole film. Norma Desmond played by Gloria Swanson is one of those characters that the audience is just waiting to break. The entire film she seems to be on the brink of a meltdown and her obsession with reviving her movie career and her romance with Joe always seem to be pushing her closer and closer to the edge. In a way I found myself loving and hating Joe, at one second I would rooting for him to escape and be with Betty but at the same time he was stringing Norma along. The use of dark and light in the film give a real feel of what life was like for everyone inside Norma's estate. Most of the scenes inside her home are quite dark and gloomy while any of the scenes in which Joe escapes are bright and jovial. This reflects Hitchcocks use of dark and light in his film Notrious. Although the audience knows the whole time that Joe is going to be murdered and the film does not let you forget it, it really draws you in with the acting and camera-work.

Author: 22 May 2022
Review_Url: I saw this movie on the Positiv channel. Could never catch it from the very beginning, but the second time I managed to see more of the beginning than I did before. I went on Wikipedia to read what happens at the beginning. I won't share any spoilers, but I will say, I'm happy I didn't see it from the opening, because the ending really surprised me. Sometimes movies that show the ending at the beginning kind of take the fun out of watching to see what happens next. A young screenwriter named Joe Gillis (William Holden), who is struggling to stay afloat due to his poor writing, moves in with a self-absorbed, emotionally unbalanced former silent film star, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), who is trying to make a comeback to the film industry. He agrees to work for her as a script doctor. She falls in love with him, and this causes problems, since he's not attracted to older women. Due to her romantic feelings not being reciprocated, she has incessant meltdowns and tries to make him feel guilty for refusing her advances. When she sees his name on a script next to that of a female's, with whom he was collaborating (Betty Schaefer, played by Nancy Olson) - and who he found himself having feelings for - she begins calling Betty repeatedly, trying to incite suspicion within her so she would stay away from him. The creepiness in this film was superbly portrayed. I also loved Joe's narration. I felt like it added an element of suspense. And Gloria Swanson was an excellent choice to play Norma Desmond. She is a really bizarre character. Her mansion is filled with nothing but pictures of herself. She has a New Year's Eve party and doesn't invite anyone. The weirdness of her personality and her vanity, along with the terror that Joe feels as he is living with her, make for a fascinating story. She's only his employer, but she starts controlling his life. She wants him to feel trapped in her house, and he is perpetually confused by her erratic behavior. Towards the end of the movie, Joe is unfazed by Norma's crying and over the top antics. There was some realism to that. When you spend time with a person who's always throwing temper tantrums, it reaches a point where it gets old. You know they have mental issues, but at the same time, you become burned out from dealing with their negative treatment of you.

Author: 22 March 2022
Review: Great dark film noir about a fallen movie star
Review_Url: There is much to love about Sunset Boulevard. First up, the directing of Billy Wilder. He lets the camera glide through the scenes and delivers a solid, fast paced narrative. Also kudos for the scriptwriter. The dialogue, or should I say Holden's monologue, is razor sharp and bitterly ironic. Then the acting; William Holden does a more than solid job but it is the performance of Gloria Swanson that really is unforgettable. Theatrical, melodramatic and all the better for it. It's a great view to a bygone era with small roles of big names from that era. The original opening sets the tone of the film perfect. Definitely worth checking out if you haven't seen it yet. And final note: a marvelous turn by Von Stroheim in the supporting role of Max the butler.

Author: 26 June 2009
Review: Bizarre, unique....and an excellent classic film
Review_Url: Despite its bizarre and tragic nature, I cannot rate "Sunset Boulevard" highly enough. What a unique film, the likes of which we simply do not see anymore. Told in flashback narration by William Holden, it tells the story of how he tried to hide from a couple of mobsters who were chasing him and accidentally stumbled across the home of former silent movie star Norma Desmond (perfectly played by Gloria Swanson). Desmond has a huge ego and believes that everyone is still in love with her films and wants her to make a comeback. As Holden is paid to write a screenplay for her, the film's tragic story begins to unfold. The story doesn't matter to this film's greatness. It's the way everything about this movie was done that makes it a timeless, excellent movie. It's some of the best dialogue you will ever hear. See the film once and you'll remember Norma Desmond forever. She is a perfect character that gives brilliant acting to every scene. For example, when Holden first recognizes her, he exclaims that she is Norma Desmond, the silent movie star who used to be big, to which she responds, in my favorite line of the film, "I am big, it's the pictures that got small!" I don't think there was a more brilliant way she could have said this. Swanson was completely robbed for Best Actress by Judy Holliday for "Born Yesterday." You will not see a film this good anymore. I can't recommend it enough. If it seems too strange, keep watching anyway, and watch a second time if necessary. Absolutely perfect.

Author: 2 March 2015
Review_Url: Joe Gillis (Holden), a Hollywood screenwriter, is in a difficult period of his professional career. While he is escaping from the debtors he finds an old house that looks abandoned, but it is not. Norma Desmond (Swanson), old glory of the silent movies era lives there. Joe agrees to review a terrible script that the diva is writing, dreaming of a sensational return to the set. The atmosphere of the house is black, dark, almost deadly. The diva projects continually her old movies, guests are mummies, this fact proves that she is obsessed with herself and her career. Relevant figure is the domestic Von Mayerling (Stroheim), he is also the first husband of Norma. She ends up falling in love of the young man, but Joe is in love with his colleague Olson. Gillis for a while accepts the situation but then he starts to be worried and afraid. But Norma, now mad and out of her mind, shoots him while he is leaving. Man falls into the pool, a symbol of the things he had so desired. Norma became mad because she doesn't want to accept the fact that she is not a star anymore, she doesn't want to accept that she is old and not anymore young and beautiful: during the film she tries to look younger thanks to clamorous long beauty treatments; she doesn't want to open her eyes and she doesn't want to see the truth. The story is told by Gillis, who is already dead, in the third person in a long flashback. Everything in the film is dusty, old, broken and decadent. The tragic music and the colors of the pictures help raising the effectiveness of the story. Everything is specifically about the world of the cinema: the dialogs, the life of the cinema studies, even the legendary gate of Paramount. This film is not traditionally dramatic, it is a unique film noir.

Review: A good homage to every important film genre before 1950.
Review_Url: Story wise, it's good. It starts off with a film noir style introduction that feels slightly forced, but the movie has a self-awareness about it that doesn't try to make fun of movies as much as it pokes fun at how silent films had become extinct and how movie making had changed. The movie quickly switches genres like Zombieland. One scene is straight out of film noir; another scene is out of a screwball comedy. It is easy to see how the movie comes together after seeing the first scene, but it gets increasingly interesting and unpredictable until the final moment when you really can see how everything happens. The final scene feels like a glorious send off with lighting present everywhere showing how much technology is necessary for a glossy scene of glamor. Parts of the movie felt like watching someone else in the movie watching a movie. Also I was eating a blueberry muffin while watching it and that made it better for me.

Author: 7 August 2020
Review_Url: It's funny how a film that's so much about the writing process in Hollywood has maybe on of the greatest scripts ever. I watched this movie for the first time ever today, 70 years after it was released, and it's still an incredibly gripping and entertaining movie, with complex characters, constantly making morally ambiguous decisions. The film is about a struggling writer who happens upon a manipulative, egocentric, middle-aged silent era movie star, who can't let go of the golden age of the past. I've heard some people call this a criticism of Hollywood, but I don't think that's right, at least not to the extent of saying that the film is primarily about that. I think it's about not being able to let go of the past, as Joe says to Norma at the end of the film "There's nothing wrong with being 50, as long as you're not trying to be 25." I probably paraphrased a little, but that's the idea. It has some pretty solid acting, as well. But really, to me, what stands out is the script, the characters and the dialogue. It's a great movie.

Author: 26 March 2003
Review_Url: Insufferable in some respects, although perhaps purposefully so. The story dragged on and on though the ego-trip of a silent actress who is struggling to be revived in the industry. Norma Desmond's infatuation with herself and total reliance on being 'known' is part of why I struggled so much through the film. If anything, I sympathized for Joe, forced to live with this person who expected everything to be as she imagined. What makes this film interesting is the story-within-story of the decline of the silent movie actor juxtaposed against a silent era actress acting as the silent actress in decline. The cast is full of silent actors, including Norma, and directors. Even the gossip at the end of the movie was a actor-turned-gossip in truth. Perhaps it had been a stretch for Mrs. Swanson to accept this role. I can't imagine that very many silent-era actors enjoyed the advent of 'talkies'. (possible spoiler:) Also, having the whole story told by a dead man is an interesting take on things. For all that he was murdered, he gave a rather kind story to the one who killed him.

Her lack of control as regards reality is compensated by the ever tightening grip she has on the impoverished writer who meets her. After meeting, the woman's charity ensnares the young writer, who is charged with raising this poor smoking corpse from the dustbin of history to the glare and flourish of success. Sunset Boulevard is a strange and destructive film certainly, it also has the rare distinction of being brilliant.

This is referencing actual events because a lot of the silent film actors weren't good in the talkie films. There have been other films about this including Singin' in the Rain (1952) directed by Donen and Kelly. This being the part of the plot doesn't seem like it would make it a classic. Author: 6 November 2017
Review_Url: Film Noirs come in all sorts of different portrayals. They range from familial conflicts such as Mildred Pierce, to watching another's internal struggle such as "Sunset Boulevard." It was a strange and beautiful movie, being extremely dramatic and dark, appearing to almost model Norma Desmond after her actress, Gloria Swanson in a strangely intimate way. So many characters of the movie were real people that I wondered if it were based off of a true story. To find out that it was not made for a more confusing and wondrous experience after watching. William Holden's narration was a comical and interesting addition to the story that fit nicely in place, and added a touch of omnipresence to his character, Joe Gillis after his death. "Sunset Boulevard" was a dark and wonderful movie, enjoyable and iconic down to the very last line.

Review: One of Billy Wilder's directorial gems
Review_Url:
This film surely deserves the credit it gets. Billy Wilder effectively creates darkly comedic dialogue in its script. The dialogue is witty, and while dark, helps shed some humor in the midst of a dark situation--this adds to the brilliance of the dialogue.
The characters are brilliantly crafted and developed, as we understand our main characters and their motivations. We understand the perspective of our two major characters, played by William Holden and Gloria Swanson. We know more about their characteristics and their goals/motivations through their dialogue and actions.
Not only is the script great, the acting is very good. Gloria Swanson creepily plays her character with a dark but brilliant delivery of dialogue, adding to the dark atmosphere of the film. William Holden also delivers his lines just as well as Swanson does.
The production design is also very fitting for the dark and creepy atmosphere of the film--the design/decoration of sets such as the house of Norma Desmond--helps add to the frightening/dark mood of the film.
I could go on and on about what makes this movie so great--and what also makes it a must-see for movie lovers. I just hope that Hollywood doesn't make a remake out of this.

Review_Url: As a rule, I'm against gratuitous remakes of film classics, but the cynical yet poignant story told in Sunset Blvd. is so timeless that it could easily be redone every ten years or so, like A Christmas Carol, with each version chronicling the slow decent into madness of a different fading movie star and his show business contemporaries due to their abandonment by Hollywood. For example, Sunset Blvd. 2002 could star Jack Nicholson as Norman Desmond and Roman Polanski as Max. They spend their evenings screening Chinatown again and again while complaining bitterly about the "weasles at Paramount" who won't return their calls. Jack sits stooped over his typewriter for days on end, adding yet another scene to his mammoth comeback screenplay, 'Five More Easy Pieces', while Roman pens phony fan letters for his deluded boss, scented with Chanel #5. Jack works tirelessly each day except Wednesday, when Warren Beatty, Peter Fonda and Karen Black come over and, between bong hits and hands of canasta, swap bittersweet stories of the good old days of Hollywood, before "the suits" took over. Jack's downfall is completed when naive young screenwriter Heather Graham rejects his leering attempts at seduction and is found face down in Jack's swimming pool, bludgeoned to death with his best putter.

Review: A Tale as Relevant Today as it was Then
Review_Url: Billy Wilder's Sunset Boulevard tells the story of Joe Gillis (William Holden), a young emerging screenwriter from Ohio struggling to build a career and make ends meet in Hollywood. After evading loan sharks in a high-speed car chase, he blows a tire and peels out into a seemingly abandoned mansion located on the titular street. It turns out to be the residence of silent movie star Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson), who has long ago been chewed up and spit out by the movie-making machine that is Hollywood. She tells him that she had been expecting him when in all reality she was expecting a man bringing a coffin for her recently deceased pet monkey. Little does Gillis know that he was soon to become its replacement. Desmond ensnares Gillis with hopes of relaunching her movie career in the era of "talkies" (movies with audio), convincing him to move into the mansion to live with her and her butler, Max (Erich von Stroheim).

Author: 5 August 2020
Review_Url: There is a lot to love about this movie, which is loaded with great performances, and intersects film noir with fading Hollywood stardom. It grabs us from the start with police called to the scene of a mansion with a body floating in its pool, and as we listen to a deadpan narrator. Director Billy Wilder gives us the first of what will be many great shots, this one from what appears to be the bottom of the pool, with policemen in the background standing over the body. The film then flashes back to a young writer (William Holden), down on his luck and pressured by repo men, trying to figure out a way to sell his work or borrow some money. He pulls into the driveway of a mansion by chance, and finds himself slowly entangled in another trap, that of an aging Hollywood star (Gloria Swanson). The feel is eerie from the start, as she seeks funeral arrangements for her pet chimp, lives in boundless ostentation, and has a single companion, her solemn servant (Erich von Stroheim) who plays an organ that otherwise wheezes drearily when the wind blows through it. While her pool and tennis courts have fallen into ruin, she lives in the past, surrounded by her own photographs and watching her own old movies. Out of what he feels to be necessity, he begins working for her and living with her, hating every moment. Gloria Swanson, who was 51, turns in an outstanding performance, and has several fantastic scenes. The one where she and Holden sit in the dark with the projector light going through smoke is brilliant, and one of my favorites. Another is him dancing with her on the floor that she says Valentino had danced on, surrounded by an orchestra and expecting other guests, only to realize there will be none. The one where she imitates Charlie Chaplin, complete with a little tramp outfit, is truly special. Wilder is excellent at gradually revealing just how far gone she is. It was a nice touch of his to include silent movie stars as her bridge companions in a small scene, including Buster Keaton, and to see Cecil B. DeMille on the set at Paramount was fantastic. We see both her delusion of still being an important star as she rolls up to the gate house in her expensive old car (an Isotta-Fraschini), and yet we also see her past stardom recognized by one of the gate keepers, and then people on the set when they realize she's there. It's a very touching moment. Things get more complicated when Holden begins working with the fiancé (Nancy Olson) of his affable friend (Jack Webb, soon to be better known for Dragnet). Not all of the scenes revolve around Swanson, and the one where Holden and Olson play act a romantic scene at a party is intelligent, funny, and utterly charming. The film gives us a behind the scenes look at Hollywood - brainstorming over scripts, the writing process, the vanity of those in the limelight, and the opulence. Swanson gets a little over the top at times especially towards the end, but the film feels both sadly true, and yet also fantastical, with her mansion other-worldly and not unlike that of the one Miss Havisham has in 'Great Expectations', as Holden observes early on. With such a setting and those poignant overtones, and having excellent direction, cinematography, script, and cast, it's hard to go wrong with this one.

Review: Great film considering when it was made; taking account it was during the hays code and the year it was made (1950)
Review_Url: I thought that Sunset Blvd. was very intriguing the way it was filmed and the was it was scripted. Personally, "film noir style" doesn't appeal to me very much but the character development and plot made it worth the while. Norma's crazy, huge ego minded personality set in the rustic mansion contrasted with Joe's low income, easily persuaded (by money) character along with his romance with Betty sustained my interest for sure. The film makers really hyperbolized each of the characters most prominent traits, such as Normas batty behavior and Betty's soft, aspiring personality. I think this type of scripting brought the film to life and made up for the lack of colour. (of course, colour wasn't possible at the time) What added to the film was the symbolism throughout, and the irony of Norma being played by Gloria Swanson, previous silent film star. Overall, I found the film was very well rounded in the sense that it wasn't just a love story, but a clever, witty, dark, and emotionally touching piece made in a time where this was very hard to find.

Author: 4 July 2018
Review: Must watch for serious cinephiles and others alike.
Review_Url: I don't have to talk about Sunset Boulevard as the film is highly rated as it is. This is a great noir film, brilliantly lit and acted. The premise is simple: A Hollywood screenwriter chances upon an aging actress who orders him to rework a screenplay. He is relocated to her mansion- which is as much as a character as she is, and soon he realizes that not only is he trapped, but that the mysterious aging actress is a loose nut. Billy Wilder's film was a massive success upon release and its reputation has only grown since. William Holden is well cast as the tragic young scriptwriter and Gloria Swanson is magical as the elusive silent screen siren. This is dark comedy of the highest order.

Author: 26 December 2002
Review: An argument for black and white
Review_Url: There are three reasons why I love this movie: Billy Wilder, Gloria Swanson, and black and white photography.  Don't misunderstand me, I love the other actors (Holden is his usual solid self)in this film, but Swanson's performance has to be one of the small handful of all-time great performances by a leading actress (my other favorites are Meryl Streep in Sophie's Choice, Bette Davis in All About Eve, and Katherine Hepburn in The Lion In Winter).  Unfortunately for Swanson, All About Eve was released in the same year, so Swanson and Davis cancelled each other out and Judy Holliday stole the Oscar for Born Yesterday, one of the All-time Oscar travesties.  Swanson puts it all out there for us in this film, and we all get to just eat it up.  She's nothing short of mesmerizing in this film...just try not to pay attention to her and you'll see what an act of futility that is.

Author: 15 October 2020
Review: Did a good job at being unsettling
Review_Url:
Sunset Boulevard had me internally yelling the entire way "What are you doing?!". I guess it was extremely unsettling to me to see Gillis becoming dependent on the riches of such a painfully fragile yet egotistical woman. To say the least, it was just uncomfortable to observe the path that Gillis was taking himself through - he had a much more promising future working with Schaffer. Yes, he may have been close to drowning in Desmond's wealth, and could (maybe) have a shot at potentially enhancing her mediocre scripts to fit the likings of the people at Paramount, thus earning him a (very) dependant living. But did he really want that? I don't particularly think so. I feel like he was almost accepting his "fate" with a sort of resentment. Because he felt like he didn't really have a choice, because he thought he had a shot with giving her reputation a face lift. Eventually I'm pretty sure he started to realize that he couldn't stay with this lady anymore, that he needed to turn his life around and go back, find his own friends his own age, working with people his own age.
I think Schaffer alluded to many opportunities and chances Gillis could take to work with her, such as when Gillis had enough of Desmond and decided back to his friend Green to inquire on whether or not Green could give him a few nights at his place. Then he was subsequently informed by Schaefer that she believed one of his scripts had potential - and was almost abruptly turned down in return when he declined. Or when Mayerling divulged to him the nearly unfathomable fact that it was in fact he who was really writing and sending the fan mail to Desmond. Because clearly no one found much taste in her work anymore. And her fame was vanishing. Fast.
I feel like the entire time he was almost battling an inner doubt within him - to find wealth and work with a seemingly crazed older lady with a fragile ego, or sign a deal with Schaffer who comprehended that his work had potential. I feel like he was in a way not really sure what he was getting himself into in the first place - he was $300 in debt, no one would lend him anything, and he started to develop mutual relations with this old woman. The ending was almost scary to me. He completely lost his chances with Schaffer. It was like his double life was seriously messing with his thinking too. The second Desmond revealed the firearm, I was 99.9% sure he wasn't leaving the estate alive (the 0.01% I was reserving for a miracle. I mean, you never know with this woman who seemed dazed to the point of becoming schizophrenic-like at the final ending shot). Somehow when she was following him with the gun I still hadn't connected the dots to the shot at the start with the dead body in the pool. But then, yes - it all made sense in a landslide.
Overall, if the film was meant to be perceived as unsatisfying/settling to their primary audiences, well it worked for me.

The character of Norma Desmond is one of a somewhat forgotten actress of the silent era who believes it is time for her great comeback to the silver screen. There is one problem though, she is a loon. Outright over the top whack job who obsesses on her career. Swamson is over the top. Very believable at times and as well, very laughable. Author: 17 March 2003
Review_Url: Joe (William Holden) is a young screenwriter down on his luck and is struggling in Hollywood to make ends meet after leaving a news reporting job in Dayton, Ohio to pursue a screenwriting career in Hollywood. While avoiding the repo man Jo make a left turn into a situation he will never forget.  The driveway he turns into is none other than the famous silent screen diva Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson) who lives in an amazing decrepit Hollywood mansion. Norma Desmond is a once famous movie star who is having problems facing the reality that stardom is no longer part of her life. Norma has been working on a script for a movie that would star her as the lead character propelling her back into her superstar status. Norma hires Jo to refine the script housing him conveniently above the garage. Jo being broke cannot refuse the offer. When water damage forces Jo to move into the main house Jo becomes more tangled in the web of the temptress Norma.  Jo becomes a kept man receiving expensive clothes and trinkets from Norma and loses touch with his life as a budding screenwriter. Opportunities for romance are faltered by the meldding Norma with Jo getting fed up with it all wanting to return to Ohio but he does not make it. Norma gets her final close-up from the news reporters who engulf her mansion to capture footage of the once famous movie star turned murderer.
