Author: 24 April 2017
Review_Url: There is too much to say about this film in just 10 lines, especially considering I did this for my breakdown. Since that focuses primarily on cinematography and sound, I will talk about plot and acting. Joe Gillis, played by William Holden, is our alienated main character who gets caught up in debt with his lenders. Joe finds reprieve from his debtors and his Hollywood apartment when he comes across a deserted mansion belonging to silent film star Norma Desmond, played by Gloria Swanson. Swanson's performance in a word is chilling. Her delivery is purposely melodramatic to play off of her silent film techniques and her outdated conception of films. Her career is essentially dead and Joe's arrival provides an opportunity for her revival. Norma is one of film noir's most famous femme fatales, considering her obsession with Joe causes her to shoot him in the end. In the aftermath, Norma's delusions about her resurgence in film causes her to think the reporters crowding her estate are cameramen filming a scene for a new film. Norma's delusional perceptions of her own reality lead to her own demise and Joe's faith in her delusions led to his demise. The wisest character is undoubtedly Max, Norma's servant who keeps her satisfied by fueling the delusions and preserving her delicate feelings. Overall, this is a must watch film for any movie lover. The cinematography is very precise and well executed and the use of sound is specific.

Author: 18 October 2019
Review: Classic atmospheric daring story of being washed up, obsession and Hollywood of the 50s
Review_Url:
A dynamite surreal movie that got made within the usual traditional constraints of the Hollywood studio system. It's the story of a struggling screenwriter who by chance befriends an aging forgotten (and struggling) actress who is desperate for attention, a mate (and work) whilst living in almost complete isolation.
The visual atmosphere is dark, ambient and beautifully stale- incredible ...and the psychiatric narcissistic madness acted out by the main actress is fully believable. It's part mystery, part psychology a bit horror and full on art. It's full of iconic memorable lines as well. This is a must have classic dark film that is comfortably punishing to its main characters and an accurate depiction of what more than often eventually happens to those in the movie business. By the way, this is one of director David Lynch's (Mulholland drive, blue velvet, eraserhead) favourite films and has cited it as a major influence upon his work (I.e. sunset Blvd <==> Mulholland drive).

Review_Url: Norma Desmend, played by Gloria Swanson did an amazing job at portraying a mentally imbalanced person who dreams of returning to her previous life as a silent movie star. Joe gills, played by William Holden seems to be disconnected to Norma in that he lives with her and pretends to be there to write a movie script in which she is the star. The themes in this movie are still relevant issues today and that's one of the reasons I believe that this movie is considered timeless. Norma still yearns for the attention that being a movie star brings. She is holding onto her past life and therefore cannot move forward in any other aspect of her being. The movie did make me laugh in parts, at times because of Norma's disillusionment however at the end I just felt sorry for her. Like many people in Hollywood today, their acting careers fizzle out at a certain age unless they reinvent themselves significantly. This often is the case with child stars that then turn to acquire psychological issues or addictions to drugs or alcohol. I also think it is quit sad that her butler and ex husband still lives with her because he loves her. It seems like in this each character is not living but existing in their life. I think it would add a greater dimension to the film if the audience knew a bit more about max as her ex husband and the history of them.

Author: 9 April 2020
Review_Url:
This film is a fascinating character study, a classic example of what happens when a delusional actress comes to believe her own publicity. The picture is well-written, superbly cast and acted, and moves at an excellent pace, with no unnecessary scenes.
The backstory of this film is almost as fascinating as the picture itself, and is the subject of a book, available from amazon. The male lead was originally offered to Montgomery Clift, who turned it down - some say because of his involvement with middle-aged torch singer Libby Holman, who told him to reject the script. Perhaps it was just too close to home. (The life of Libby Holman would itself make a fascinating film)
According to rumor the picture was actually based on the life of Corinne Griffith, one of the most beautiful women in silent pictures, who was also a real estate expert. When Norma Desmond states "I own three blocks downtown," that was Corinne speaking - she did own three blocks in Beverly Hills.
Wilder and Brackett had been working on the script for some years when it finally jelled. The picture contains some famous lines that have become part of our folklore, such as "I'm ready for my closeup." I would recommend it to any student of the cinema, or anyone who is just a movie fan.

Author: 18 January 2019
Review_Url: At the time, Sunset Blvd. was one the movies that explored the underworld of Hollywood and its true face. It follows a struggling screenwriter and ends up in the hands of Norma Desmond, the classic femme fatale of film-noir. This movie takes a lot of risks and that's what makes it a very good movie. Many romance movies eventually end with the main guy getting the girl and they walk off the sunset. But this movie does not do that, it is very dark and it had to be work. The way it shows Hollywood as a dark place, especially during this time, by using actor or actress for a long time and then they just throw them away like an antique. It also shows that people who work in Hollywood aren't perfect people, everyone looks up to Hollywood like its a glamorous place, but the main character is trying to get away from paying his car bills and then, he also seduces a female screenwriter after she says that she is engaged. If the movie had ended with him going with Betty in the end, it would have gone against the purpose of the movie, and probably not make it a film milestone that it is today.

Review_Url: This extremely dramatic film noir was surprisingly a movie that I liked. Although at first glance, I admit I assumed it to be over the top or annoying perhaps but I was wrong, Gloria Swanson (famous silent film actress) stepped out of her silent film career to play this more well known role of her career. Surprisingly enough, this film is about Hollywood in the 1950's. William Hollden is a somewhat struggling film writer who ends up meeting Norma (Swanson). The pair make for a humorous yet strange pair throughout the entire film. The black and white film itself creates for an even more intense and certainly dramatic mood, it especially helps to atmosphere of the movie when scenes take place in Norma's gloomy old mansion. Narration throughout the film is in first person from Holden's point of view. The entire thing is a sort of- flashback, as most noirs are. Camera tricks such as fading in and out are used quite often in the film to add to dramatic effect as well. Of course the ending was my favorite part where Norma stares blankly at the screen and says " Mr. DeVille- i'm ready for my close up." I really liked this film a lot. It was visually and emotionally enticing.

The script is very clean, clever, and witty. There were a variety of camera angels, with clean transitions. I also enjoyed the element of romance throughout the film. The actors really embraced their characters and brought the script to life and made you feel emotional throughout the movie, because it seemed so realistic, and like these were real people going through hard times. The movie was shot beautifully in black and white, and gave off a very gloomy vibe. I really enjoyed this film and think it deserves all the success, because it is an interesting movie and makes you feel emotional involved. I recommend this movie to someone would wants to see a Hollywood film noir classic.

Review_Url: Forget "Citizen Kane"! Forget "Casablanca"! Forget "The Godfathers"! Forget all the John Ford's westerns! Besides, forget all that theory-of-montage-invented-by-Eisenstein stuff. Author: 12 December 2006
Review_Url: I just want to clear up a misconception about Gloria Swanson and her performance as Norma Desmond. Gloria Swanson was NOTHING like Norma Desmond in real life. At the time she was offered the role, she was very busy (thank you very much) in New York with, among other things, pioneering early live television. She had a very busy family and social life, and wasn't that keen on returning to California and the silver screen. She was, however, very intrigued with the script, and was talked into it by Wilder. When she got to the coast and began to make contact with some of her old friends from the silent days, she was very disturbed and a little freaked out to discover that there were indeed many "Norma" cases hidden in the Bel Air hills. She was shocked to find many of her old acquaintances were stuck in the past, where as she had moved on and never looked back. She then actively sought out these people and began studying them, incorporating parts of each of them into her portrayal of Norma Desmond.

Author: 24 May 2023
Review: Cruel critique of its own industry
Review_Url: The film's structure is quite unique as it starts with the ending scene of the main character lying dead in the pool. Not only is it an element of foreshadowing, it basically spoilers the whole movie. Of course, it makes you curious about the rest of the movie and how it got to this point, but I personally didn't like it because later I could already tell that things wouldn't work out for Joe and that made it harder to root for him. Another thing that was unique about the structure was the use of a narrator. It was Joe's voice talking about the events and giving us a little insight into his thoughts. That reminded me so much of how books are structured that I googled if the movie was based on a book (which it isn't). I think what was lacking for me with this movie was my connection to the characters. I couldn't understand a lot of their actions (for example why Joe stayed for that long, why Max stayed with Norma) and they were just not likable to me. I didn't really care about what would happen to them. For me, the only interesting characteristic was how different the two women in Joe's life were; they were basically opposites of each other. Betty is this young, sweet and innocent girl who is full of ideas and still has her whole career in front of her. She has realized that "being behind the stage is just as good" as being on it, while Norma craves for the spotlight and would never settle for anything other than being the main actress. Betty is looking into the future and Norma is stuck in the past, obviously traumatized by how she was treated by the movie industry. Her career is already over, but she keeps on holding on to her dreams of yesterday. Her obsession with her old self and her delusion about her career are portrayed as the result of how her directors pushed her to the side after she reached a certain age and didn't fit the beauty standard anymore. By that, the movie is critiquing its own industry and how actors are treated in it. I think it has an important message and a good movie, but it didn't really resonate with me.

Author: 27 April 2023
Review: More complex than it seems on the surface
Review_Url: Throughout film and literary history, women have often been depicted as either a damsel in need of saving or as a witch in need of controlling, and although Sunset Boulevard seems- at first- to fall into this trap, it quickly dismisses this theory. Nora Desmond can be seen by the audience as a controlling vindictive woman, but that is simply the surface of her character. Yes, she does display controlling and even sometimes abusive behavior towards Joe, particularly crying and screaming to make him feel bad whenever he does something she disapproves of, but she also has complex reasons for the way she is. We learn that she was brought into stardom at 16, and became a gigantic star, only to be cast aside and forgotten once she couldn't cut it in "talkies." She is an archetype of someone who was promised everything and had it all taken from her overnight. This is contrasted with the character of Betty, who dreams of writing scripts for movies. She was never promised success in the industry, working herself up the studio ladder. Betty never expected much from the world, no grand life in the lights of Hollywood, no romantic love story with Joe; she asks him for one, but she never expects it, and when he tells her he can't give it to her, she accepts this. Perhaps if she had expected more, she would have forced Joe to go with her then, and he would have survived.

Author: 17 May 2023
Review_Url: Sunset Boulevard is an interesting film set in early 50s Hollywood, with a couple issues. This is obviously an older movie so it had slower pacing, but it didn't detract from the film that much. Despite it's age it still had a strong plot line but unfortunately it was partially ruined by them spoiling the ending right at the beginning of the film. I don't like it when films do this, and in this case it's pretty easy to deduce what will happen at the end. This ended up taking a lot of the surprise out of what could have been a shocking ending. As for the plot itself, it follows an out of luck writer who by chance happens upon what is paradoxically his best opportunity, that is also doomed to fail. However he decides to stay and write a screenplay for bygone actress Norma Desmond, receiving a high salary even though he knows the screenplay will never take off. He had another choice he could take, to run off with Betty Schaefer, basically the complete opposite of Norma, and the film made a pretty clear contrast between the women/choices he had. He had many chances to get out of his situation, but instead he decided to essentially become a willing prisoner to wealth and riches, and ultimately paid the price for it. Overall, despite it's age it still holds up today which I think is an accomplishment by itself. Unfortunately the film didn't answer the most important question, what was the whole deal with the monkey??????
